options.label: A
options.text: All group operations must be commutative

options.label: B
options.text: All group operations must be closed or restricted to only group elements

options.label: C
options.text: All group operations must have an inverse

options.label: D
options.text: All group operations must have an identity element

multiple-choice.question: What is the identity element in the context of adding integers?
What is the purpose of the inverse element in a group?

options.label: A
options.text: To change the operation of the group

options.label: B
options.text: To cancel out another element in the group

options.label: C
options.text: To add a new element to the group

options.label: D
options.text: To remove an element from the group

multiple-choice.question: How many permutations are possible on a Rubik's Cube?
How can group theory be applied to solving a Rubik's Cube?

options.label: A
options.text: By analyzing the cube and determining a sequence of permutations that will result in a solution

options.label: C
options.text: By using a computer algorithm to solve the cube

options.label: D
options.text: By taking the cube apart and reassembling it

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the chord that can be visualized by writing out all twelve musical notes and drawing a square within them?
What is the operation that can be performed on a chord in music, equivalent to addition in group theory?
How can a Rubik's Cube be "played" like a piano, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: By covering the cube with notes and expressing the solution as a chord progression

options.label: B
options.text: By using the cube as a percussion instrument

options.label: D
options.text: By taking the cube apart and reassembling it

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that composers use inversions in music?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a blocky, awkward sounding progression

options.label: B
options.text: To manipulate a sequence of chords and avoid a blocky, awkward sounding progression

options.label: C
options.text: To change the key of a piece

options.label: D
options.text: To add a new instrument to a piece

title: How do hard drives work? - Kanawat Senanan

multiple-choice.question: What is at the heart of every hard drive, allowing it to store a large amount of information in a small space?

options.label: A
options.text: A stack of low-speed spinning discs with a recording head

options.label: B
options.text: A stack of high-speed spinning discs with a recording head

options.label: C
options.text: A single low-speed spinning disc with a recording head

options.label: D
options.text: A single high-speed spinning disc with a recording head

multiple-choice.question: How is data recorded onto the disc in a hard drive?

options.label: A
options.text: By converting strings of bits into electrical current fed through a resistor

options.label: B
options.text: By converting strings of bits into electrical current fed through an electromagnet

options.label: C
options.text: By converting strings of bits into light signals fed through a fiber optic cable

options.label: D
options.text: By converting strings of bits into sound waves fed through a speaker

multiple-choice.question: What is the areal density of a modern hard drive?
What technique allowed engineers to shrink the reader and writer in a hard drive?
What is the superparamagnetic effect in hard drives?

options.label: A
options.text: When a magnetic grain volume is too large, its magnetization is easily disturbed by heat energy

options.label: B
options.text: When a magnetic grain volume is too small, its magnetization is easily disturbed by heat energy

options.label: C
options.text: When a magnetic grain volume is too large, its magnetization is not easily disturbed by heat energy

options.label: D
options.text: When a magnetic grain volume is too small, its magnetization is not easily disturbed by heat energy

multiple-choice.question: How did scientists resolve the limitation of the superparamagnetic effect?

options.label: A
options.text: By changing the direction of recording from longitudinal to perpendicular

options.label: B
options.text: By changing the direction of recording from perpendicular to longitudinal

options.label: C
options.text: By increasing the size of the magnetic grains

options.label: D
options.text: By decreasing the size of the magnetic grains

multiple-choice.question: What is heat-assisted magnetic recording in hard drives?

options.label: A
options.text: A technique that uses a laser to heat up a particular spot on the disc and reduce its magnetic resistance

options.label: B
options.text: A technique that uses a laser to cool down a particular spot on the disc and increase its magnetic resistance

options.label: C
options.text: A technique that uses a magnet to heat up a particular spot on the disc and reduce its magnetic resistance

options.label: D
options.text: A technique that uses a magnet to cool down a particular spot on the disc and increase its magnetic resistance

multiple-choice.question: What is bit-patterned media in hard drives?

options.label: A
options.text: A technique that arranges bit locations in separate, nano-sized structures

options.label: B
options.text: A technique that arranges bit locations in separate, micro-sized structures

options.label: C
options.text: A technique that arranges bit locations in a single, large structure

options.label: D
options.text: A technique that arranges bit locations in a single, small structure

multiple-choice.question: According to Moore's Law, what happens to information density every two years?
What is the potential areal density of bit-patterned media in hard drives?

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 1 terabit per square inch

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 10 terabits per square inch

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 20 terabits per square inch

options.label: D
options.text: Up to 100 terabits per square inch

title: How computers translate human language - Ioannis Papachimonas

multiple-choice.question: Why do creators of science fiction worlds introduce the concept of a universal translator?

options.label: A
options.text: To explain how aliens learn human languages

options.label: B
options.text: To avoid depicting the lengthy process of compiling an alien dictionary

options.label: C
options.text: To demonstrate the superiority of human language

options.label: D
options.text: To explore the intricacies of intergalactic communication

multiple-choice.question: What type of database is used by a rule-based translation program?
What is the primary challenge faced by translation programs in understanding language?

options.label: B
options.text: Understanding semantics and finer points of meaning

multiple-choice.question: How does Slovene morphology pose a problem for translation programs?

options.label: B
options.text: It uses a dual suffix to distinguish between two and three or more items

options.label: C
options.text: It has a complex system of verb conjugation

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary limitation of statistical machine translation?

options.label: A
options.text: It requires a large initial database

options.label: B
options.text: It is unable to recognize basic linguistic elements

options.label: C
options.text: It is limited to translating simple sentences

options.label: D
options.text: It is unable to understand semantics

multiple-choice.question: Why do some researchers believe that human understanding of language is unique?

options.label: A
options.text: Because humans have developed advanced translation programs

options.label: B
options.text: Because humans have a biological brain structure that allows for instinctive understanding of language

options.label: C
options.text: Because humans have a limited capacity for language learning

options.label: D
options.text: Because humans rely on statistical machine translation

multiple-choice.question: What is the Babel fish from "The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy"?

options.label: A
options.text: A machine that translates languages through statistical analysis

options.label: B
options.text: A small creature that translates brain waves and nerve signals through telepathy

options.label: D
options.text: A computer program that recognizes basic linguistic elements

multiple-choice.question: What is the current most effective way to learn a language?

options.label: D
options.text: Learning a language the old-fashioned way

multiple-choice.question: What is driving the development of advances in automatic translation?

options.label: A
options.text: The increasing interaction between people who speak different languages

options.label: B
options.text: The decreasing number of languages in the world

options.label: C
options.text: The development of more advanced computer programs

options.label: D
options.text: The creation of universal translator devices

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what might be necessary if we encounter intergalactic life forms?

options.label: C
options.text: Learning the language of the intergalactic life forms

title: Real Beauty

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of the engineering design process?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a visually appealing product

options.label: C
options.text: To develop a solution that meets user needs

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following design principles emphasizes the importance of simplicity and clarity?
What is the term for the process of testing and refining a product or system to ensure it meets user needs?
Which of the following materials is commonly used in 3D printing due to its durability and versatility?
What is the term for the study of how people interact with products, systems, and environments?
Which of the following design tools is used to create detailed, technical drawings of a product or system?
What is the term for the process of evaluating the environmental impact of a product or system throughout its entire lifecycle?
Which of the following technologies is used to create interactive, immersive experiences for users?
What is the term for the process of designing products or systems that are accessible and usable by people with disabilities?
Which of the following design approaches emphasizes the importance of empathy and understanding user needs?

title: Want to survive a hurricane? Think like a tree...

multiple-choice.question: What event led to the observation of the remarkable resilience of Live Oaks on St Charles Street?
How many Live Oak trees out of over 700 died during Hurricane Katrina on St Charles Street?
What unique feature of the Live Oak's trunk helps it survive strong winds?
How do the leaves of the Live Oak tree minimize friction when hit by strong winds?

options.label: B
options.text: They curl into the shape of a Fibonacci Sequence

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the roots of Live Oak trees that helps them withstand hurricanes?

options.label: C
options.text: They are entwined with the roots of neighboring trees

multiple-choice.question: What can architects and engineers learn from the Live Oak's root system to design more hurricane-resilient buildings?

options.label: C
options.text: To design foundations with horizontal components that twine together with neighboring buildings

multiple-choice.question: Why is the current time considered a "perfect storm" for nature-inspired innovation?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we know less about the natural world than ever before

options.label: B
options.text: Because we have fewer resources available

options.label: C
options.text: Because we know more about how the natural world works than ever before

options.label: D
options.text: Because we have less technology available

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the sequence that the Live Oak leaves curl into to minimize friction?
What is the main idea that architects and engineers are exploring to design safer and more resilient buildings?

options.label: A
options.text: To design buildings that stand alone

options.label: B
options.text: To design buildings that are extremely tall

options.label: C
options.text: To think like a Live Oak tree and design buildings that work together as a community

options.label: D
options.text: To design buildings that are extremely small

multiple-choice.question: Where can viewers find more episodes of "Think Like a Tree"?

title: How a few scientists transformed the way we think about disease - Tien Nguyen

multiple-choice.question: What theory did people believe caused diseases like the cold, flu, and strep throat for several centuries?
What was the name of the physician who led the charge in proving that germs cause diseases?
What symptoms experienced by cholera-infected patients led Dr. Snow to believe that the disease was transmitted through food or drink?
What was the location of the water pump that Dr. Snow suspected was the source of the cholera outbreak in 1854?
Why did Dr. Snow suggest that cholera was spread through a poison in the water instead of microorganisms when presenting his case to governmental officials?

options.label: A
options.text: He was unsure of the true cause of the disease

options.label: B
options.text: He knew how unpopular germ theory was

options.label: C
options.text: He wanted to simplify the explanation

options.label: D
options.text: He wanted to alarm the officials

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of shutting down the Broad Street pump?

options.label: B
options.text: New cases of infection remained the same

options.label: D
options.text: The outbreak spread to other areas

multiple-choice.question: Who isolated the cholera-causing bacterium in 1884, vindicating Dr. Snow's efforts?
What was the contribution of Louis Pasteur to germ theory?

options.label: C
options.text: He discovered the existence of microorganisms

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the workhouse located around the corner from the Broad Street pump in Dr. Snow's investigation?

options.label: A
options.text: It was the source of the cholera outbreak

options.label: B
options.text: It had a high rate of infection

options.label: C
options.text: It had its own private well, which explained the low rate of infection

options.label: D
options.text: It was not relevant to the investigation

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the efforts of scientists like Dr. Snow, Dr. Koch, and Louis Pasteur?

options.label: A
options.text: They proved that miasma theory was correct

options.label: B
options.text: They discredited an age-old theory and sparked a revolution in public health

options.label: C
options.text: They failed to make any significant contributions to germ theory

options.label: D
options.text: They caused widespread panic and fear

title: Why do women have periods?

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following mammals are known to menstruate?

options.label: A
options.text: All primates, including lemurs and lorises

options.label: B
options.text: Monkeys, apes, bats, humans, and possibly elephant shrews

options.label: D
options.text: All mammals, but with varying frequencies

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for the evolutionary conflict between a mother and her fetus?

options.label: A
options.text: The mother's body tries to reject the fetus as a foreign entity

options.label: B
options.text: The fetus inherits genes from its father that can promote its own survival at the mother's expense

options.label: C
options.text: The mother's body is not adapted to nourish the fetus

options.label: D
options.text: The fetus is not genetically compatible with the mother

multiple-choice.question: In humans and a few other species, how does the placenta access the mother's bloodstream?

options.label: A
options.text: Through a barrier of maternal cells

options.label: B
options.text: By penetrating directly into the mother's circulatory system

options.label: C
options.text: By fusing with the mother's cells

options.label: D
options.text: By creating a separate circulatory system

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the fetus's placenta in regulating the mother's blood supply?

options.label: A
options.text: It restricts blood flow to the fetus to prevent excessive nutrient uptake

options.label: B
options.text: It pumps hormones into the mother's arteries to keep them open and provide a permanent flow of nutrient-rich blood

options.label: C
options.text: It has no direct role in regulating the mother's blood supply

options.label: D
options.text: It reduces the mother's blood pressure to prevent hypertension

multiple-choice.question: Why is pregnancy considered a significant investment for the mother?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it requires significant emotional and psychological resources

options.label: B
options.text: Because it can lead to intense fatigue, high blood pressure, and conditions like diabetes and preeclampsia

options.label: C
options.text: Because it requires significant financial resources

options.label: D
options.text: Because it can lead to social isolation

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the endometrium in the uterus?

options.label: A
options.text: To facilitate implantation of the embryo

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent implantation of the embryo

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the mother's hormonal balance

multiple-choice.question: What happens when an embryo fails to implant or dies during the early stages of pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: The mother's body absorbs the embryo and continues with the pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: The embryo is expelled from the uterus, but the endometrial lining remains intact

options.label: C
options.text: The womb gets rid of its endometrial lining, along with any unfertilized eggs, sick, dying, or dead embryos

options.label: D
options.text: The mother's body experiences a severe immune response

multiple-choice.question: What is the biological process known as menstruation, and what is its primary function?

options.label: A
options.text: Menstruation is the process of ovulation, and its primary function is to release an egg for fertilization

options.label: B
options.text: Menstruation is the process of implantation, and its primary function is to facilitate fetal development

options.label: C
options.text: Menstruation is the process of removing the endometrial lining, and its primary function is to protect the mother from infection and potential harm from a failed pregnancy

options.label: D
options.text: Menstruation is the process of childbirth, and its primary function is to deliver the baby

multiple-choice.question: Why do humans menstruate more frequently than other animals?

options.label: A
options.text: Because humans have a shorter gestation period

options.label: B
options.text: Because humans have a more complex reproductive system

options.label: C
options.text: Because humans have a higher risk of pregnancy complications

options.label: D
options.text: The transcript does not provide a clear answer to this question

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of the biological process of menstruation?

options.label: C
options.text: To protect the mother from infection and potential harm

options.label: D
options.text: To set the stage for the continuation of the human race
